pageData.text: In this investigation, students will build and analyze simple <button class='glossary-text'>circuits</button> using miniature lamps as resistors. <button class='glossary-text'>Current</button> flows through a closed circuit. The brightness of the lamps acts as an indicator of the relative current through each loop of the circuit, thus enabling students to understand how <button class='glossary-text'>voltage</button> and current are used in series and parallel circuits.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Scissors
Ruler
Tape (recommended but not required)

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 10 minutes 
Activity 1: Resistors in Series – 15 minutes
Activity 2: Resistors in Parallel – 15 minutes 
Activity 3: Circuits with Resistors in Series and Parallel #1 – 15 minutes 
Activity 4: Circuits with Resistors in Series and Parallel #2 – 15 minutes
Activity 5: Circuits with Resistors in Series and Parallel #3 – 15 minutes

Develop an understanding of <button class='glossary-text'>voltage</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>current</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button>

pageData.text: One of the easiest ways to reduce your home energy consumption is to switch from traditional incandescent lightbulbs to LED lightbulbs. Some states and countries have even banned incandescent lightbulbs as a way to reduce their carbon footprints. LEDs are much more efficient and last up to 30 times longer than incandescent bulbs, and they are safer and easier to dispose of than Compact Fluorescent Lights (CFLs), which contain mercury.  LEDs can produce the same amount of light while using about 75% less energy. Some of this is due to the <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button> that each of the types of bulbs provides to the electricity flowing through it. Bulbs have to provide some amount of resistance in order to slow down the electrons to allow them to do work and produce light (either through incandescence or electroluminescence for LEDs). The tungsten filament of an incandescent bulb has a high resistance, which is necessary to heat up the filament and make it glow. But as a result, up to 90% of energy input is converted to heat and is unusable to produce light. In an LED, almost none of the energy is converted to heat. Instead, almost all energy is used to produce light meaning that there is less energy input needed to produce the same brightness<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

1Harris, W., & Freudenrich, C. (2023, March 8). How light works. HowStuffWorks Science. Retrieved from
https://science.howstuffworks.com/light9.htm

pageData.altText: A strip of small LED lights

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Circuits</button> are an integral part of modern life. Built into the infrastructure of modern towns, circuits carry <button class='glossary-text'>power</button> to homes and businesses, control the flow of traffic, and extend the number of workable hours by providing light at night. More complicated electrical circuits, such as those found in radios and computers, have intricate circuits that allow them to perform complicated functions, process and transfer complex information, and generally make life more convenient. However, regardless of their complexity, all circuits work according to the same basic principles (Figure 1).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A multimeter device attached to two probes by wires is resting on a complex circuit board

pageData.text: A circuit is a complete path or loop that allows for the transfer of . For a charge to flow, the circuit must be complete.

A simple circuit requires three elements:
  1. A source which provides the force to move charge through the circuit
  2. A conductive path which connects the elements or components in a circuit
  3. A load or which uses electricity to do work

The most basic function of a circuit is to transfer charge, which is a physical quantity like mass, time, or distance. There are two types of charge—positive and negative. Objects with like charge repel each other, while objects with dissimilar charge are attracted to each other.

Electrical circuits allow charge to flow through various components connected by wires. This charge is carried by electrons in the metal atoms that compose the wires. The electrons are in constant random motion until an is established, at which point the electrons follow the electric field. As they move through the circuit, the electrons transfer charge.

The force that drives the charged electrons through a is called an or . A is a source of electrical potential. When a lamp is connected to a battery, the difference in electrical potential between the positive and negative side of the battery draws the negatively charged electrons through the circuit, providing energy to light the lamp. When a circuit is complete, the electrical potential or voltage causes to move through the circuit. This movement of charge is called a . Electrical current is simply an expression of the number of electrons passing a certain point in the circuit in a certain amount of time. The amount of current is measured in Amperes, which is abbreviated as amp (A). An amp is equal to the number of coulombs (a unit of charge) per second.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: [A] equal C divided by s

pageData.text: One <button class='glossary-text'>coulomb (C)</button> is a very large amount of charge. For example, an average lightning bolt may transfer approximately 15 coulombs of charge. The <button class='glossary-text'>elementary charge</button> is the charge of one electron (e), which is equal to 1.602 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>−19</sup> C. The current moving through a circuit is often measured in milliamps (1 mA = 1 A × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>−3</sup>) or microamps (1 μA = 1 A × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>−6</sup>). These relatively small units demonstrate that miniscule amounts of charge flow through circuits at any time. However, some circuits, such as those carried by <button class='glossary-text'>power</button> lines, conduct large currents and can be dangerous.
Voltage and are related to each other through another quantity called , which is a measure of how much an object opposes the flow of current. This relationship is described by , which states.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: V equal I times R

pageData.text:
V = voltage (, measured in Volts [V])
I = current (measured in Amperes or amps [A])
R = resistance (measured in Ohms [Ω])

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A diagram of a circuit with one resistor

The symbol in Figure 3 represents a resistor, and the symbol in Figure 4 represents a <button class='glossary-text'>voltage</button> source.

pageData.question: A circuit is a complete path or loop that allows for the transfer of charge. For a charge to flow, the circuit must be complete. Which of the following is NOT required to complete a simple circuit?

options.text: a current
a voltage source which provides the force to move charge through the circuit
a conductive path which connects the elements or components in a circuit
a load or resistance which uses electricity to do work
All of these are required to complete a circuit.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>circuits</button> shown throughout this lab are <button class='glossary-text'>Direct Current (DC)</button> circuits, which entail any given loop of the circuit having the <button class='glossary-text'>current</button> flowing in one direction. Batteries provide a source of a direct current. The current delivered from <button class='glossary-text'>power</button> stations is an <button class='glossary-text'>Alternating Current (AC)</button> which is a current that oscillates back and forth between a positive and negative <button class='glossary-text'>voltage</button>, changing directions very quickly. The advantage to having an alternating current is that it can be transmitted over greater distances without losing much energy. Electrical devices that require a direct current have power supplies that transform the AC output from wall outlets to a lower voltage, as well as convert the current to DC.

Note: When analyzing and drawing circuits, the direction of current follows the flow of positive . This is known as “.” In reality, the positive charges in atoms are due to the protons in the nucleus, which do not move when a circuit is connected. When a circuit is connected, it is the electrons in the outer energy levels of atoms that move. The electrons carry a negative charge, so electric current is a flow of negative charge. When this happens, it has the net effect of a positive charge flowing in the opposite direction. Electrical power systems and appliances were already in wide use before this discovery was made, and it had been assumed that current was due to a flow of positive charge; so by convention, people agreed to keep using positive current. The arrows indicating the flow of current on diagrams in this document are all indicating the flow of positive,“conventional” current.

When different components or devices are connected in a circuit, they draw energy. This energy can be used to run a motor or power a computer, but in all cases, some of this energy is converted to heat. A light lamp converts electrical energy to heat and light. The intensity of a light lamp, which is indicated through its brightness, depends on the power dissipated throughout the lamp. The power dissipated through the lamp, or any resistor, depends on the voltage across this resistor and the current through the resistor.

pageData.altText: Equation 3: P equal V times I

pageData.text:
P = power (measured in Watts [W])
V = voltage (, measured in Volts [V])
I = current (measured in Amperes or amps [A])
Just like mechanical energy, power translates into Joules per second, demonstrating that it is a measure of energy per unit time.

pageData.altText: Equation 4: [P] equal [V] times [S] equal J divided by  C times C divided by s equal J divided by s equal W

pageData.text:
In addition to , Kirchhoff’s rules can be used for analyzing and in a :
  1. :
    The sum of the differences around any closed loop in a circuit is zero.
  2. :
    The current flowing into a junction must equal the current flowing out of a junction.

The following labs in this manual include a series of increasingly complex circuits that will illustrate the relationship and differences between voltage and current by applying the principles of Ohm’s law and Kirchhoff’s rules.

pageData.question: What does Kirchhoff’s voltage rule state?

options.text: The sum of the electrical potential differences around any closed loop in a circuit is zero.
The current flowing into a junction must equal the current flowing out of a junction.
V=IR
Power (P) is measured in Watts [W].
Power (P) translates into Joules per second (J/s).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Voltage and current are related to each other through another quantity called resistance, which is a measure of how much an object opposes the flow of current. This relationship is described by Ohm’s law, which states V=IR. Kirchhoff’s voltage rule states the sum of the electrical potential differences around any closed loop in a circuit is zero. Kirchhoff’s current rule states that the current flowing into a junction must equal the current flowing out of a junction. The following labs in this manual include a series of increasingly complex circuits that will illustrate the relationship and differences between voltage and current.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Voltage and current are related to each other through another quantity called resistance, which is a measure of how much an object opposes the flow of current. This relationship is described by Ohm’s law, which states V=IR. Kirchhoff’s voltage rule states the sum of the electrical potential differences around any closed loop in a circuit is zero. Kirchhoff’s current rule states that the current flowing into a junction must equal the current flowing out of a junction. The following labs in this manual include a series of increasingly complex circuits that will illustrate the relationship and differences between voltage and current.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activities 1-2 of this investigation. To prepare, cut and strip the wires. Then, test the batteries, lamps and clips in the circuit. In activity 1, assemble a series circuit with lamp, batteries, wires and clips. Then, observe the brightness of the lamp and record your observations. Next, photograph and disconnect the circuit. Then, add an additional lamp and repeat the process. Once you have observed circuits with R1, R2 and R3 lamps, disconnect the circuit. In activity 2, assemble a parallel circuit with lamps, batteries, wires and clips. Then, observe the brightness of the lamps and record your observations. Next, photograph the circuit. Then, unscrew one lamp, observe the brightness of the other lamp and record your observations. Next, disconnect the circuit. Then, add an additional lamp in parallel and repeat the process. Once you have observed circuits with R1, R2 and R3 lamps, you will disconnect the circuit. Proceed to activity 3.

A map of the procedural workflow for activities 3-4 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, assemble a series and parallel combination circuit. Then, observe the brightness of the lamps and record your observations. Next, photograph the circuit. Then, unscrew the specified lamp, observe the brightness of the other lamps and record your observations. Repeat the process to test both the R1 and R2 lamps. In Activity 4, assemble a series and parallel combination circuit. Then, observe the brightness of the lamps and record your observations. Next, photograph the circuit. Then, unscrew the specified lamp, observe the brightness of the other lamps and record your observations. Repeat the process to test the R1, R2 and R4 lamps. Record the resistors from brightest to dimmest, then disconnect the circuit. Proceed to Activity 5.

A map of the procedural workflow for activity 5. After completing activity 4, in activity 5, assemble a series and parallel combination circuit. Then, observe the brightness of the lamps and record your observations. Next, photograph the circuit. Then, unscrew the specified lamp, observe the brightness of the other lamps and record your observations. Repeat the process to test both the R1 and R3 lamps. Record the resistors from brightest to dimmest, then disconnect the circuit.

pageData.text: Read all of the instructions for this laboratory activity before starting the activity. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Procedure section.

The components included in this kit use low <button class='glossary-text'>voltage</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>current</button> and are safe to handle. Do not substitute other components with this kit.

Connecting <button class='glossary-text'>circuits</button> for extended periods of time can cause wires or components to overheat or batteries to leak. Keep the circuits connected only as long as is needed to complete the analysis, and then disconnect the alligator clip from the batteries.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What will happen to the voltage when the current stays the same and the resistance is increased?

options.text: The voltage will increase.
The voltage will decrease.
There will be no change.
The voltage will cause a reversal in current.
More information is needed to answer.

assestmentData.question: What is the difference between AC and DC?

options.text: In AC the current oscillates between negative and positive charge, while in DC it stays the same.
In AC the resistance is close to zero, while in DC the resistance is much greater.
In DC the voltage is always higher than the amperage, in AC they are the same.
In DC the current goes clockwise, while in AC the current goes counterclockwise.
In DC the current oscillates between positive and negative, while in AC it stays the same.

options.text: Do not substitute other components with this kit.
Keep the circuits stored in the refrigerator when not in use.
The batteries included in this investigation are highly flammable.
Conduct this investigation in a well-ventilated area.
The components included in this kit use high voltage and current.
A circuit where the current can take several paths.
A circuit where everything is in one line.
An open circuit that is not connected to the power source.
A circuit where the same current goes through every resistor.
A circuit where there are no resistors.

assestmentData.question: In a circuit which is in series, how does the current go through three different lamps?

options.text: The current passes from one lamp to the next.
The current will alternate between one lamp and the next.
The current will increase from one lamp to the next.
The current will not go through the lamps.
The current will be used up as it moves through the lamps.

assestmentData.question: What does Kirchhoff’s second rule say about current?

options.text: The current flowing into the junction must equal the current flowing out of a junction.
The current flowing into a junction is greater than the current flowing out of the junction.
The current flowing into the junction is smaller than the current flowing out of the junction.
The current flowing through a junction flows faster going out.
The current flowing through a junction will dissipate when flowing out of a junction.

typeBefore.text: The circuits in these activities use lamps as resistors. All of the lamps and sockets are identical so that each lamp can be considered to have a <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button> of “R” Ohms.

Diagrams are included to show the circuits representing the lamps with the resistor symbol and the <button class='glossary-text'>battery</button> with the <button class='glossary-text'>voltage</button> symbol. Photographs are also included of the assembled circuits showing exactly how the lamp sockets are connected.
There is one voltage source in each <button class='glossary-text'>circuit</button>, which can be considered as having volts (V).
By adding resistors and loops to the circuit, the <button class='glossary-text'>current</button> through the lamps and voltage across the lamps will change.

Since the brightness of the lamp depends on <button class='glossary-text'>power</button>, and power depends on current and voltage, changing the current and voltage in different parts of the circuit will change the relative brightness of the lamps.
Note: The brightness of the lamps depends on power, which depends on both current and voltage. Power through a resistor is represented as:P = VI = V2 /R = I2R

pageData.text: Use scissors to cut the copper wire into 10 strips that are each 10 cm long.

Use the sandpaper to remove the enamel from the last 3 cm of each end of each piece of wire. Make sure the enamel is cleared from all sides of the wire. Watch the following video on how to strip magnet wire.
Insert a battery into a battery holder.
Screw a miniature lamp into each one of the miniature sockets as shown in Figures 5 and 6. The metal tip at the base of the bulb should contact the metal plate on the lamp socket.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: A lamp holder and socket with a copper wire looped through and tied around the metal clip of the socket

pageData.text: Tip: Make sure the terminals on the lamp holders are not touching, and screw in the light bulb until the base of the bulb touches the contact on the lamp holder.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: A lamp holder and socket with a copper wire looped through and twisted around the socket's metal clip, like a twist tie

pageData.text: Connect one of the wires to each terminal of the lamp sockets by pressing down on the metal clip and sliding the magnetic wire through it (see Figure 5). The connection needs to be secure, so you may need to fold or twist the end of the copper wire so that it is a little thicker. Alternatively, tie the wire around the socket’s wire clip as shown in Figure 6.
Connect one end of the alligator clip/black electrode to the end of one piece of attached magnet wire. Attach the other end to one of the metal “ears” at the end of the battery holder.

Connect the other alligator clip/black electrode wire to the open magnetic wire and the open “ear” on the battery holder. The light bulb should illuminate. For further troubleshooting see “Troubleshooting Tips” at the end of this Preparation section.

Once you have a good connection, remove the end of one alligator clip/black electrode from the battery holder and unscrew the bulb from the holder. Check each of your remaining bulbs to ensure they illuminate. If one or two do not, don’t worry—your set includes extra bulbs.
Note: Only leave circuits connected long enough to observe the brightness of each light. Using too high a voltage or leaving the circuit connected too long may burn out the lamps.

Troubleshooting Tips: If at any time you feel the bulb is too dim to see, troubleshoot using the following steps:
  1. Make sure the bulb is neither loose nor off-center. If you suspect a bulb is defective or may have burned out, use the circuit shown in Figures 8 and 9 to test the bulb. If the bulb does not work, replace it.
  2. Ensure that the wires and other circuit components all have stable connections. You may need to pull gently on the wires to tighten the connections. Once the connection is stable, you may wish to tape the lamp sockets to the work surface to help hold the circuit together.
  3. If Steps a and b do not work, then add one additional battery and battery holder to the system. The battery holders snap together. The alligator clips should attach to the outermost “ears” on the holder, as shown in Figure 7. Add just one battery and holder at a time until the bulb brightens. Connecting an excessive number of batteries without testing may blow out the bulb.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: A circuit with two resistors; battery holders are also shown, with alligator clips connected to the battery holders
Figure 8: A diagram of a circuit with one resistor
Figure 9: A photo of a circuit with one resistor, which is represented by a lamp; alligator clips are connected to the circuit

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will assemble a series <button class='glossary-text'>circuit</button> and observe the brightness of the lightbulb. You will then add additional lightbulbs in series and observe the brightness of the lightbulbs for each new circuit.

Construct the <button class='glossary-text'>circuit</button> as shown in Figures 8 and 9 using one lamp, one lamp receptacle, and one <button class='glossary-text'>battery</button> in a battery holder. Connect the alligator clips/black electrodes as shown in Figure 9.

pageData.text: Screw in the lamp, then connect the remaining ends of the alligator clips/black electrodes to the battery holder.
Observe the brightness of the lamp; then, record your observations in the Lab Notebook. Take a photograph of the circuit while it is connected.

Assemble a circuit with two lamps in series as shown in Figures 10 and 11. Connect the wires by twisting them together as shown in Figure 11.

Figure 11: A circuit with two resistors, which are represented by two identical lamps

Connect three lamps in series as shown in Figures 12 and 13.

pageData.text: Observe the brightness of the lamps; then, record your observations in the Lab Notebook

pageData.text: Disconnect the circuit by removing one of the alligator clips from the batteries.

In Activity 2, you will assemble a parallel <button class='glossary-text'>circuit</button> and observe the brightness of the lightbulbs. You will then add an additional lightbulb in parallel and observe the brightness of the lightbulbs for each new circuit. You will also disconnect one of the lightbulbs in the parallel circuits and observe how the brightness of the remaining bulbs changes.

In Activity 3, you will assemble a <button class='glossary-text'>circuit</button> with a combination of parallel and series lightbulbs and observe the brightness of the lightbulbs. You will then disconnect designated light bulbs and observe how the brightness of the remaining bulbs changes.

Disconnect the lamp in position R<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>. Photograph the circuit and record your observations in the Lab Notebook.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Disconnect the circuit by removing one of the alligator clips from the batteries.
In Activity 4, you will repeat steps similar to Activity 3 for a different combination <button class='glossary-text'>circuit</button>.

pages.title: Circuits with Resistors in Series and Parallel #2
pages.pageTitle: Circuits with Resistors in Series and Parallel #2 (13 steps)

pageData.text: Construct the <button class='glossary-text'>circuit</button> as shown in Figures 20 and 21.

pageData.altText: Figure 20: A diagram of a circuit with four resistors; one is in a series and three are in parallel with each other
Figure 21: A circuit with four resistors; one is in a series and three are in parallel with each other

pageData.text: Photograph the circuit while all of the lamps are connected.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Data Table 1, write the name of the remaining resistors in order from brightest to dimmest.
Disconnect the lamp in position R<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>. Observe the brightness of the lamps and photograph the circuit.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Data Table 2, write the name of the remaining resistors in order from brightest to dimmest.
Reconnect resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>.
Disconnect resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> and take a photograph of the circuit.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Data Table 3, write the name of each resistor in order from brightest to dimmest.
Reconnect resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>.
Disconnect resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>4</sub> and photograph the circuit.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Data Table 4, write the name of each resistor in order from brightest to dimmest.
Disconnect the circuit by unhooking one of the alligator clips from the <button class='glossary-text'>battery</button> pack.
Record your observations in the Lab Notebook.
In Activity 5, you will repeat steps similar to Activities 3 and 4 for a different combination <button class='glossary-text'>circuit</button>.

pages.title: Circuits with Resistors in Series and Parallel #3
pages.pageTitle: Circuits with Resistors in Series and Parallel #3 (8 steps)

pageData.text: Construct the <button class='glossary-text'>circuit</button> as shown in Figures 22 and 23.

pageData.altText: Figure 22: A diagram of a circuit with four resistors; one is in a series and three are in parallel with each other
Figure 23: A circuit with four resistors; one is in a series and three are in parallel with each other

pageData.text: Observe the brightness of each lamp. Record your observations in the Lab Notebook. Photograph the circuit with all the lamps connected. In Data Table 5, write the name of each resistor in order from brightest to dimmest.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Disconnect resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>. Observe the brightness of the lamps.Photograph the circuit and record your observations in the Lab Notebook.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Data Table 6, write the name ofthe remaining resistors in order from brightest to dimmest.
Reconnect resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>.
Disconnect resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>. Observe the brightness of the lamps. Photograph the circuit and record your observations in the Lab Notebook.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Data Table 7, write the name of each resistor in order from brightest to dimmest.
Disconnect the circuit by unhooking one of the alligator clips from the <button class='glossary-text'>battery</button> pack.

text: Make sure the alligator clips are detached from the terminal.
Carefully unscrew the lamps from the socket. Put them back in the lamp container.
Dispose of any burned out lamps in the trash receptacle.
Take the batteries out of the <button class='glossary-text'>battery</button> holder.
Put everything back into the materials kit. Clean up the work area.

text: Consider the circuit from Activities 4 and 5. Based on the brightness of the lamps when they are all connected, which current is the greatest?  Which current is the smallest?
What happens to the lamps when resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> is disconnected?
What happens to the lamps when resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> or R<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub> is disconnected?
What happens to the lamps when resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>4</sub> is disconnected?
Which exhibits the larger voltage drop, R<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> or R<sub class='bodysubscript'>4</sub>?
Why is the voltage drop across resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>4</sub> greater than the voltage drop across resistor R<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>?
If all the lamps have equal resistance, what is the total resistance in the circuit?
What would happen to the brightness of the lamps if another resistor were added in series with R<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> (e.g. between points B and C).  Why?

Equation 1: [A] equal C divided by s
Equation 2: V equal I times R
Figure 2: A diagram of a circuit with one resistor

Figure 4: The symbol for a voltage source

A map of the procedural workflow for activities 1-2 of this investigation. To prepare, cut and strip the wires. Then, test the batteries, lamps and clips in the circuit. In activity 1, assemble a series circuit with lamp, batteries, wires and clips. Then, observe the brightness of the lamp and record your observations. Next, photograph and disconnect the circuit. Then, add an additional lamp and repeat the process. Once you have observed circuits with R1, R2 and R3 lamps, disconnect the circuit. In activity 2, assemble a parallel circuit with lamps, batteries, wires and clips. Then, observe the brightness of the lamps and record your observations. Next, photograph the circuit. Then, unscrew one lamp, observe the brightness of the other lamp and record your observations. Next, disconnect the circuit. Then, add an additional lamp in parallel and repeat the process. Once you have observed circuits with R1, R2 and R3 lamps, you will disconnect the circuit. Proceed to activity 3.

A map of the procedural workflow for activities 3-4 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, assemble a series and parallel combination circuit. Then, observe the brightness of the lamps and record your observations. Next, photograph the circuit. Then, unscrew the specified lamp, observe the brightness of the other lamps and record your observations. Repeat the process to test both the R1 and R2 lamps. In Activity 4, assemble a series and parallel combination circuit. Then, observe the brightness of the lamps and record your observations. Next, photograph the circuit. Then, unscrew the specified lamp, observe the brightness of the other lamps and record your observations. Repeat the process to test the R1, R2 and R4 lamps. Record the resistors from brightest to dimmest, then disconnect the circuit. Proceed to Activity 5.

A map of the procedural workflow for activity 5. After completing activity 4, in activity 5, assemble a series and parallel combination circuit. Then, observe the brightness of the lamps and record your observations. Next, photograph the circuit. Then, unscrew the specified lamp, observe the brightness of the other lamps and record your observations. Repeat the process to test both the R1 and R3 lamps. Record the resistors from brightest to dimmest, then disconnect the circuit.
Figure 5: A lamp holder and socket with a copper wire looped through and tied around the metal clip of the socket

data.title: Alternating current (AC)
data.content: A current that oscillates back and forth between positive and negative voltage in a circuit

data.title: Battery
data.content: A container consisting of one or more cells, in which chemical energy is converted into electricity and used as a source of power

data.title: Charge
data.content: A basic property of matter carried by some elementary particles that governs how the particles are affected by an electric or magnetic field

data.title: Circuit
data.content: A complete path or loop that allows for the transfer of charge

data.title: Conventional current
data.content: The direction of current following the flow of positive charges when analyzing and drawing circuits

data.title: Coulomb (C)
data.content: A unit of electric charge; the quantity of electricity transported in one second by a current of 1 amp (A)

data.title: Direct current (DC)
data.content: A current that flows in only one direction around a circuit

data.title: Electric field
data.content: A region around a charged particle or object within which a force would be exerted on other charged particles or objects

data.title: Electrical potential
data.content: The force that drives electrons through a circuit; also known as voltage

data.title: Elementary charge
data.content: The charge of one electron which is equal to 1.602 x 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>-19</sup> C

data.title: Kirchhoff's current rule
data.content: States that the current flowing into a junction must equal the current flowing out of a junction

data.title: Kirchhoff's voltage rule
data.content: States that the sum of the electrical potential differences around any closed loop in a circuit is zero

data.title: Ohm's law
data.content: States that the voltage of a circuit is directly proportional to the product of the current and resitance of a circuit

data.title: Power
data.content: The amount of energy transferred or converted per unit time

data.title: Resistance
data.content: The measure of how much an object opposes the flow of current

data.title: Voltage
data.content: An electromotive force or potential difference expressed in volts; also known as electrical potential
